summary: This document is an academic research article titled 'Women's Reporting of Sexual and Physical Assaults to Police in the National Violence Against Women Survey' by Yingyu Chen and Sarah E. Ullman. It analyzes factors influencing women's decisions to report sexual versus physical assaults to police using data from the National Violence Against Women Survey (NVAWS). The article compares victim demographics, assault characteristics, and reporting patterns, finding both similarities and differences in reporting decisions between the two types of assaults. This document is an academic research article titled 'Comparing Police Reporting of Sexual versus Physical Assaults from the National Violence Against Women Survey' by Chen and Ullman. It presents statistical analyses comparing factors influencing police reporting of sexual assaults versus physical assaults using data from the National Violence Against Women Survey (NVAWS). This document is the final pages of an academic article titled 'Chen and Ullman 277' (likely a reference list and author bios) from the journal 'Violence Against Women'. It contains a bibliography of scholarly works on rape reporting, victimization, and criminal justice responses, followed by author biographies for Tilton Chen and Sarah E. Ullman. It is not a primary case document but part of the academic literature included in the released files.

events.title: Presentation at Academy of Criminal Justice Sciences
events.description: The research was presented at the annual meeting of the Academy of Criminal Justice Sciences in Cincinnati, Ohio.

keyFacts: The study uses data from the National Violence Against Women Survey (NVAWS), conducted between November 1995 and May 1996, involving 8,000 women in the United States.
Findings indicate that 74.9% of assault incidents went unreported, 17.7% were reported by victims, and 7.4% were reported by third parties.
Sexual assault victims were significantly younger (mean age 22.1) at the time of assault compared to physical assault victims (mean age 28.5).
Physical assaults were more likely to involve physical force (92% vs. 33%), weapons (16% vs. 9%), and occur at the victim's home (69% vs. 40%) than sexual assaults.
The study compares correlates of reporting for sexual and physical assaults, noting that factors like victim age, marital status, and physical force influence reporting differently by assault type.
This document is an academic research article, not a direct legal or investigative document related to the Epstein case. It appears to be misfiled or included in the dataset erroneously.
The study analyzes data from the National Violence Against Women Survey (NVAWS) to compare factors influencing police reporting of sexual assaults versus physical assaults.
Key finding: Sexual assaults were significantly less likely to be reported to police than physical assaults (only 10.6% reported by victim vs. 22.2% for physical assaults).
The study found high similarity in correlates of police reporting between rapes and physical assaults, contrary to assumptions that rape reporting is unique.
The sample consisted of 2,072 cases (804 sexual assaults and 1,268 physical assaults) from a national survey of women.
This document is a bibliography and author bios for an academic article on rape reporting and victimization, not a primary Epstein case record.
The authors, Tilton Chen and Sarah E. Ullman, are researchers in criminal justice and psychology focusing on sexual assault.
The content references numerous scholarly studies on rape myths, reporting rates, and criminal justice system responses, indicating the file may contain background research material.
